comments.commentBody:
But this is still going to collect less revenue than the current Millionaires' tax, no?

Despite a somewhat more graduated rate for the actual working and middle classes, it sounds like the biggest feature of this deal is a huge tax break for those making between $200,000 and $2 million. Under this structure, they'd pay less than they do now, and the state will still lack revenue. And without that revenue, we're likely to see cuts--and who will those most likely hurt?

Very cynical on Cuomo's part. A tax break for the 98th percentile and the lower part of the 99th percentile is not a progressive tax structure, even if it comes with a tax hike for the top 0.5%!
Bud, go there and don't come back!
Kathleen from PA, you are dead wrong.  Obama is hardly a "Socialist."  Are the Koch Bros. paying you to write all of these comments blasting people that don't agree with you?

Good move - make it undesirable for the wealthy to live in New York, or the US for that matter, and they will leave.  That's why its called mobile wealth.  If you think we have a corner on quality of life - look it up - we have one of the lowest rankings in the developed world.  Hello Monaco!
A good start. Now if we could get other states and the Congress to follow suit, we might avoid having a nation of oligarchs and wage slaves, and save the middle class.
Confiscate people's earnings?  Extracted money?  Doens't sound like Home of the Brave, Land of the Free.  Jealousy is a destructive emotion.

Job Producers? More agitprop from Republican Orwellians to describe the Superich 1% who don't want to see a dimunition of their extravagant lifestyles. Actually, the current politically correct term (based on Mitch MConnel and Boehner's recent speeches) is "Job Creators". When you hear this, you must immediately translate to "undertaxed 1% Superich". For ten more  examples of current Republican Doublespeak intended to obfuscate class warfare, see Paul Farrel's column in todays (12/6) online Market Watch, which amazingly enough is a Wall Street Journal publication (wonder how long before Farrel gets the boot from them).

I'm sick and tired of hearing about the hard-done-by job creators. The last time I checked, unemployment was close to 9% officially and substantially higher unofficially. They're not creating jobs, so they should have to subsidize the outcome of that, which is large amounts people not working and paying taxes on the income they'd be making. And how is it going to hurt Cuomo and Obama? Have you actually LOOKED at the jokers the GOP is fielding as candidates these days?
Cuomo for President

Because it's all about getting votes. Take from a minority to buy majority votes.

Support unions and benefits though there is no budget to do so in order to gain more votes.

Democrats: champions of the common vote.

Backwards on so many levels. My family get's by comfortably enough in Westchester on $100,000 and your family can't survive on $300,000? I rent a small house in Westchester that my father has tried to sell for $275,000, but you cannot find house under $550,000? And the only people on unemployment who won't go back to work are people who can only find jobs making far less than what they were at their previous jobs, and fair and decent people don't expect them to do that. You're not being honest.
Those poor minority rich people, right Middle of the Road?

Why is there never a discussion of the huge differences in the cost of living and wages across New York State? I grew up in Western NY and have lived in NYC and metro area for the last 15 years. I can tell you my married couple friends who are pulling in $100,000 -200,000 a year in WNY with houses under $180,000 and far better public schools are living a much easier financial life than me and my husband who will just hit the $300,000 and can't find a house for less than $550,000. Add the cost of actually getting to work anywhere in the metro area and filling school gaps with tutors.
Yes, I could move out of this area, and my friends are fortunate to have well paying jobs west of here, they certainly aren't plentiful but plenty of people ARE working in good jobs for their region across the state. There are many factors and choices - in NY and across the country for cost of living / quality of life. The dialogue and tax schematics however I believe need to start incorporating income level vs. cost of living.
While we are at it, stop extending unemployment benefits and you will see people go back to work. I hear it every time I am back home, "why should I work full time when I get unemployment?". And clean up the medicare fraud, est at over $3 billion A YEAR in NY - that alone would equal these new tax "benefits." We need to invest millions in saving billions on fraud in this state.
Yeah because Alabama is just so great when compared to the greatest city in the world and the gorgeous Adirondack Park.
Oh well time to move to a less taxed State
That's an assumption on your part that the "state" will miss anyone fleeing for the south. And likely not a correct one. Sorry.

How many more New Yorkers will become Florida residents, leaving here this month and returning the end of May?. Many who worked so hard to succeed  do that in order to benefit from the a more favorable tax rate. I miss them and so will this state.

Am I crazy or just over-tired from my low-paying job?  How can losing $2 billion in revenue be applauded?  I can't even tease this out.  I believe that this is beyond Orwell's double-think; its quadruple-think. This does mean a loss of $2billion dollars in state revenue, correct?  How is that fiscally responsible?  Help.

I will agree $40,000 is by no means a lot of money, but there are plenty of places in NY where you can buy a house for $40,000. Can you buy a house for your annual salary where you live?
These income levels almost mean nothing because the cost of living across NY varies wildly.
Everyone should pay taxes. The family making $40,000 a year is likely living in a place where the cost of living is 25% of yours - would you say someone making $160,000 a year in Westchester shouldn't pay taxes?

I know people living in good neighborhoods in Western NY in $80,000 gorgeous houses, driving brand new cars, dining out, traveling - the answer may be to give businesses incentives to spread out across the state.

I know some in the 1% here in the city. I count them among my friends. (I am not, unfortunately, one of them). They are all very comfortable here. The idea that they would uproot their lives and move to New *gag* Jersey because of a 1% tax increase on their hefty incomes makes them giggle.
People don't move to new states for tax reasons. They move where the jobs are, and RICH people don't need to move for anything!

Youre clueless. Go check on google the Port Authority cops earning $350K/year with overtime as they spike their salary just prior to retiring...

The NY Post has done numerous stories on it, which we of course will never see in the public union employee-loving NY Times.
Because Texas is suicidally boring and New York isn't?

Because new York is a great place to live, particularly with money.  NYC is one of the most diverse and cultural cities in the world.  Life in NYC, when you have money, is fantastic.  Even without much money it's wonderful.  I pay .50 to get to the Metroploitan Museum.
We have water and temperatures below 100 degrees
Texas thanks you New York.  Your millionaires will enjoy the warm weather down south as well as a thriving economy.  Why would anyone with money live in New York?

And when the 10,000 show up, all demanding jobs that pay at least $850,000 (because that's what they earned here in NY), what will you offer them?  Wal*mart greeter?  People don't move 200 miles for tax reasons.
They will move to Texas and create jobs there.  New York will be the less for it too.
Interesting you pick Venezuela.  One of the few countries with as much inequality as the USA.

I agree in all respects.  I don't see how anyone can assess this purported plan based on the lack of detail in this article.  Readers don't know the facts and don't care that they don't know them.  The details can, and surely will, have big consequences.

Apples and oranges.  And the highest Oregon rate affects many, many fewer people.  Not to mention that Oregon's tax rates for lower-income people is much higher than New York's:  A couple making $16K in New York is taxed at 4.5%.  The same couple in Oregon is taxed at 9%.  Sounds much tougher to be lower-middle class in Oregon.
What? Where about Hillary in 2016?

You are correct, and I am glad you are correct as I'm in the bracket you identify as getting a reduction. (Although in your "Big Deal" paragraph you erroneously say that bracket's rate will be reduced to 6.65% when it is actually 6.85%.)

Everyone wants a "millionaires" tax, but couples earning $300K and living in NYC, are not millionaires and they certainly aren't the "super rich". In Iowa, perhaps they are, but not in NYC.

Thank you for saying what is rarely said:  a middle-class income in NYC is multiples of what is in almost anywhere else in the country.  I've never understood that federal income tax rates don't take cost of living into account.  Living in a small rental apartment in Brooklyn and paying the same rate as the wealthiest person in Iowa is just plain ridiculous.
